rev.comment: replace 'search appliances' with 'enterprise products', and add details on Google Apps Premium Edition.
rev.diff:
Line 73: Line 73:
Most of Google's revenue is derived from its online advertising programs.<ref name="claburn">Claburn, Thomas. "[http://www.informationweek.com/showArticle.jhtml?articleID=172302900 Google Revenue Doubles]." ''Information Week.'' [[October 20]], [[2005]]. Retrieved on [[February 23]], [[2007]].</ref> Google [[AdWords]] allows Web advertisers to display adverts in Google's search results and the Google Content Network, through either a cost-per-click or cost-per-view scheme. Retrospectively, with Google [[AdSense]] Website owners can display adverts on their own site, and earn money every time it is clicked.
Most of Google's revenue is derived from its online advertising programs.<ref name="claburn">Claburn, Thomas. "[http://www.informationweek.com/showArticle.jhtml?articleID=172302900 Google Revenue Doubles]." ''Information Week.'' [[October 20]], [[2005]]. Retrieved on [[February 23]], [[2007]].</ref> Google [[AdWords]] allows Web advertisers to display adverts in Google's search results and the Google Content Network, through either a cost-per-click or cost-per-view scheme. Retrospectively, with Google [[AdSense]] Website owners can display adverts on their own site, and earn money every time it is clicked.
â
===Search appliances===
+
===Enterprise products===
â
Google has created two kinds of physical search tools, including Google Mini and Google Search Appliance, which are for small/medium businesses and large corporations respectively. They can index internal documents, and provide search facilities for [[Intranet]] and Web applications.
+
In [[2007]], Google launched [[Google Apps|Google Apps Premium Edition]], a software suite for businesses that provides [[e-mail]], [[instant messaging]], [[calendar]], [[word processing]], as well as a [[spreadsheet]] program.<ref name="graham">Graham, Jefferson. "[http://www.usatoday.com/tech/products/2007-02-22-google-apps_x.htm?csp=15 Google goes after Microsoft with software suite]." ''[[USA Today]].'' [[February 22]], [[2007]]. Retrieved on [[February 23]], [[2007]].</ref> This product is targeted primarily at the business user, and intended to compete directly versus [[Microsoft]]'s [[Microsoft Office|Office]] suite, with a price of approximately $50 per user per year compared to $500 per user for Microsoft Office.<ref name="graham"/>
==Platform==
==Platform==
